text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today 
instead of cooking I've decided to teach you a few

useful Thai words that will help you read a Thai 
restaurant menu see most high restaurants like

to use the time names of the dishes but then 
write them out in English phonetics which is

great but if you don't know what those words mean 
then it doesn't tell you anything about the dish

so just knowing a few useful words can actually 
help you quickly find what you're looking for

without having to read all the little fine print 
descriptions under the names so today I've got

a few thai restaurant menus here that I went 
around town and grabbed them and I looked for

words that came up over and over again so those 
are the words that we'll go through and then at

the end I'll show you how you can use your new 
vocabulary to help you read a Thai restaurant

menu next time you go so first let's look at all 
the big animals we've got gai which means chicken

moo sounds like it should mean cow but it really 
means pork neua, nua means beef now there's a couple

of spelling variations for Neua because different 
restaurants tend to spell things differently and

this is the case for a lot of the vocabs coming 
up so I'll just show all the spelling variations

together bped means duck now moving on to seafood 
we've got goong meaning shrimp pla means fish pla

meuk literally translates to Inc fish but it means 
squid bpu means crab hoi is a general term that

includes all the bivalve molluscs like clams 
mussels scallops and oysters talay Talay means

the sea but in the context of food it refers to 
a dish that uses multiple types of seafood in it

so the next category of words are the cooking 
techniques we've got Pad which means to stir-fry

this will include all fried Rice's fried noodles 
as well as anything that uses a wok such as pad

thai yum yum is a type of salad and if you see 
multiple types of yum on the menu chances are

they use the exact same dressing tom means 
soup usually a brothy kind of soup gang gaeng

means curry but it doesn't always mean the 
rich coconutty kind of curry like a green

curry it could also be a brothy curry like gang 
ba which is also known as the jungle curry Tod

means to deep fry and this will show up a lot 
in the appetizer section neung this doesn't come

up very often but it means to steam and it 
will come up usually in the seafood section

and finally we've got a few miscellaneous words 
that also come up sometimes we've got prik which

means chilly grob which means crispy and this 
will usually means the thing is deep fried kao

means rice ped means spicy and don't confuse the 
word bped with bped which actually means duck and

sometimes different restaurants will spell them 
exactly the same way so that's the only two that

can be confusing and then finally if you're 
vegetarian you want to look for the word pak

means vegetables and if the word pak is in the 
name of the dish the dish chances are there's

no meat in that dish you still want to ask the 
restaurant and check for fish sauce and oyster

sauce but at least you know that there's no meat 
in it so let's see how your newfound vocabulary

can help you read a Thai menu so let's take a look 
at this menu and let's say you're at a restaurant

and you're feeling like fish and you remember from 
hot tide kitchen that fish is splat so I'm looking

here at the seafood section so with just one quick 
look at the seafood section I already see that

number 46 47 and 48 I'll have my pla in it so 
these are the dishes that I want to consider and

I also recognize that number 43 here has the word 
pla but that's not fish because you remember that

pla meuk or Inc fish is a squid so let's take a 
look at another example now a lot of restaurants

like to categorize things according to the types 
of protein they use for example let's look at this

chicken section here so here on this list you see 
that this whole list is chicken but you recognize

that Pad all these are stir fries because you know 
that Pad means stir fries which is really helpful

in this case because in the description it doesn't 
even say how the chicken is done it just gives you

a list of ingredients so but you know that it's 
a stir fry and also you recognize kaeng kaeng and

kaeng here and you remember that that means curry 
so already if you're in a mood for curry you

quickly know that all you have to think about 
is these three and ignore all the rest of them

and that's all for today I hope learned a thing 
or two and next time you go to a Thai restaurant

you'll be able to read a menu more easily for a 
list of all these words that I just went through

and visit my website at hsn.com and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious title
